abstract: When the government said it would spend $700 billion to rescue the nation’s financial industry, it seemed to be an ocean of money. But after one of the biggest lobbying free-for-alls in memory, it suddenly looks like a dwindling pool, The New York Times’s Mark Landler and David D. Kirkpatrick write.
lead_paragraph: When the government said it would spend $700 billion to rescue the nation’s financial industry, it seemed to be an ocean of money. But after one of the biggest lobbying free-for-alls in memory, it suddenly looks like a dwindling pool, The New York Times’s Mark Landler and David D. Kirkpatrick write.

headline.main: Lobbyists Swarm for a Helping of the Bailout Pie
